broom.helpers 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Identify for each coefficient of a model the corresponding variable

model_identify_variables.Rd

It will also identify interaction terms and intercept(s).

model_identify_variables(model)

# S3 method for default
model_identify_variables(model)

# S3 method for lavaan
model_identify_variables(model)

Arguments

model

a model object

Value

A tibble with four columns:

  • term: coefficients of the model

  • variable: the corresponding variable

  • var_class: class of the variable (cf. stats::.MFclass())

  • var_type: "continuous", "categorical", "intercept" or "interaction"

See also

tidy_identify_variables()

Other model_helpers: model_get_contrasts(), model_get_model_frame(), model_get_model_matrix(), model_get_xlevels()

Examples

Titanic %>%
  dplyr::as_tibble() %>%
  dplyr::mutate(Survived = factor(Survived, c("No", "Yes"))) %>%
  glm(Survived ~ Class + Age * Sex, data = ., weights = .$n, family = binomial) %>%
  model_identify_variables()
#> # A tibble: 7 x 4
#>   term             variable var_class var_type   
#>   <chr>            <chr>    <chr>     <chr>      
#> 1 (Intercept)      NA       NA        intercept  
#> 2 Class2nd         Class    character categorical
#> 3 Class3rd         Class    character categorical
#> 4 ClassCrew        Class    character categorical
#> 5 AgeChild         Age      character categorical
#> 6 SexMale          Sex      character categorical
#> 7 AgeChild:SexMale Age:Sex  NA        interaction

iris %>%
  lm(
    Sepal.Length ~ poly(Sepal.Width, 2) + Species,
    data = .,
    contrasts = list(Species = contr.sum)
  ) %>%
  model_identify_variables()
#> # A tibble: 5 x 4
#>   term                  variable             var_class var_type   
#>   <chr>                 <chr>                <chr>     <chr>      
#> 1 (Intercept)           NA                   NA        intercept  
#> 2 poly(Sepal.Width, 2)1 poly(Sepal.Width, 2) nmatrix.2 continuous 
#> 3 poly(Sepal.Width, 2)2 poly(Sepal.Width, 2) nmatrix.2 continuous 
#> 4 Species1              Species              factor    categorical
#> 5 Species2              Species              factor    categorical
